text: On a windswept walk in Carmarthen... Make money work for you.
It sounds very realistic... It's probability that makes things believable.
I've been talking through what happens in the war game with Chris Donnelly... He does, and he's explaining why.

What most people are not aware of is the fact that had World War III started during the Cold War, not Germany, but the UK would have been the first target... Because we were the US unsinkable aircraft carrier.

He's referring to how the US Air Force used to station dozens of squadrons in the UK during the Cold War... As well as the historic factor, there are very modern reasons for Vladimir Putin's Russia to want to target Britain.
Putin sees the UK as enemy number one in Europe... We are the country which in Russian eyes has stood out most against what he's doing in Ukraine.
There is one other key factor. Nations like Poland and the Baltic states... hold Britain in particularly high regard.
The reality of our military weakness isn't seen... There are two really good reinforcing reasons that make your scenario in the bigger picture actually far from improbable.
What you're about to hear is the kind of war game that's genuinely tested inside government... Episode 4, Ultimatum.
So shortly we will be reading the ultimatum. Okay, very good.
The Russia team is preparing for what's known as the next turn in war game language.
All happy? I think we're okay, thank you.
In the real world, the players in our imagined Kremlin are completely separated from the British side... Unlike the British Blue Team, the Russians know the main moves they will make.
So our primary objective remains to neutralize the United Kingdom as an opponent and as an obstacle to what we wish to achieve. Yes, absolutely.
As they step back into character, the president asks his top general and his military spy chief how they think the UK will respond... while Maria Enkvist from Sweden is the head of the GRU.
Chief of Military Intelligence, your view, please.
It is our assessment that the capabilities of the United Kingdom are so uneven... So our assessment is that the situation basically has not changed. Thank you.
Chief General Staff. I would also add that as the result of this confrontation... seriously threaten our interests in Europe.
On the British side of the basement, the participants have been enjoying a lunch break of sandwiches and crisps. But the only topic of conversation is the game.
You're giving us a… this is happening fast, isn't it? Very fast.
They have no idea what's coming next.
For God's sake, we've got to unearth this intelligence. Yes! So not us. Completely, you know.
What's happened to the second aircraft carrier? Has it propeller fallen off on the way round?... It's always our fault.
In the war game, it's now 9.30 in the morning on Monday 6 October 2025... Rob Johnson, the Oxford academic who's running the scenario, signals to everyone that it's time to return to their seats.
Right, ladies and gentlemen, we're back in Cobra. Back in the womb.
The players assemble for a new Cobra emergency meeting.
Right, are we ready to go?
We're ready to go. Each participant receives a map of the UK... Rob, speaking in his role as chair of the Joint Intelligence Committee, then shares the latest intelligence update.

It appears that the Russian surface force that we heard of earlier is located at location 2 on a map heading north rapidly... Anti-ship missiles are directed against the UK Type 45 that's currently in the North Atlantic.
Russia has just launched a second wave of strikes... The Royal Air Force fighting alone without NATO allies is woefully outgunned compared to the Russian forces attacking them.
We believe it will take about 20 minutes for the missiles to arrive on Cheltenham and on London... That concludes the intelligence brief.
Right, OK. Right, so... While these missiles are in the air, are we in position to shoot them down?... but shoot the people who launch them.

General Sir Richard Barons, as Chief of the Defence Staff, or CDS, says his Air Force will do what it can against the cruise missiles, while a single Type 45 warship at sea is the only piece of equipment capable of shooting down any ballistic missiles.
Which is the same Type 45 that's dealing with anti-ship missiles being fired at it... So we're going to have a maritime fight now.
The Defence Secretary, played by James Heapey, has an even more immediate worry.
My first concern is that we've got 60 minutes remaining of time of flight... I wonder if the Home Secretary has any understanding of the state of our missile warning systems air raid alarms.
Amber Rudd as Home Secretary is also very alive to the threat to life.
The Prime Minister reminds his colleagues this is something the authorities would automatically be doing, despite a lack of practice about how to act in a state of war.

The emergency services are a bit like the military in a sense of on an automatic response without having to bring it back to Cobra. All we get from defence is it's coming your way and then they do the rest.
Prime Minister, what is the rest here? Because in the absence of any kind of civil defence organisation these days, are we advising people to stay at home and be a sitting duck?

Jack Straw, in the role of Foreign Secretary, is referring to the Civil Defence Corps, which was formed at the start of the Cold War but disbanded in the late 1960s... up to and including nuclear war.
In the war game, our imagined first responders are doing the best they can.
We have taken the initiative, Foreign Secretary, of letting the specific areas that are going to be targeted know... And everybody else to stay at home.
Lord Marks-Edwell is the national security adviser.
We're going to be dealing in 10 minutes with mass casualty events and the emergency services are just going to have to respond to that. Nothing we can do in this room is going to change that.

These missiles are going to strike and the time we have remaining, the most useful thing we can do is get ahead of this and tell people what has happened and what they should now do because this will be overwhelming in terms of damage and uncertainty.
It seems to me that one of the things that we have to do is take lessons from what happened in Ukraine.
Helena Kennedy as the Attorney General.
We never know where the Russians will fire at next... But it's better than running them out into the street where a thing might land.
PM, these missiles are going to strike within the next minute or two... but with that strategic aim of dividing NATO.
Suddenly, confirmation comes in of the missile strikes.
Prime Minister, I've just been informed that missiles have struck on locations here in London... The damage report will be coming up very shortly.
A map flashes up on a big screen showing central London. Four red circles identify the location of the four areas in the capital that were impacted.
Four locations have been struck.
The team tries to work out exactly what's been hit.
Had the strikes happened for real, one of the targets is in Whitehall, so they would have heard the impacts and maybe even felt the blast waves.
Looks like the Admiralty Building... Wellington Barracks over there.
Looks like Oxford Street. Oxford Circus... Whether that was intentional or not, who knows.
The National Security Advisor is given precise information on the damage.
So the strikes against London were the MOD Oxford Street, Wellington Barracks, Milbank. Emergency services are responding.
This second wave is far more public than the first and the effect will be even more traumatising for the country.
Yeah, OK, OK.
Our imagined news channel is rolling live on the crisis.
Behind the scenes, the newsreader is handed an update by her producer.
OK, we'll stay on air... Police say there are casualties
Two ballistic missiles have hit Oxford Circus.
They crash down just outside the tube station entrances where Oxford Street meets Regent Street, killing two people and wounding several more.
On a normal Monday morning, this intersection of shops and cafes would have been fairly busy, but most people followed the instructions to stay at home, so the number of casualties is mercifully low.
With the country reeling a Downing Street spokesperson has repeated calls for the public to stay at home if you can and await further information.
The damage to buildings on Oxford Street is devastating... They've had to deal with so many strikes like this.
On Oxford Street, the strike tears two giant craters in the road... Twisted lumps of metal and other pieces of shrapnel are strewn in all directions.
Two cruise missiles hit the Ministry of Defence... The blast wave rattles the windows of government buildings along Whitehall.
Two more missiles blast into an office block in Milbank... The fourth site is Wellington Barracks, a military base near to Buckingham Palace.
Casualties are 32, of which at least two have been killed... So, good work by the military there.
Two military facilities elsewhere in the country appear to have been hit. We've been asked not to give further details for security reasons.
At Lossiemouth they hit three Typhoon aircraft, ten casualties, Coningsby buildings, no casualties.
Lossiemouth in Scotland and Coningsby in Lincolnshire are the bases from where the British fast jets would have scrambled to defend against the strikes.
Then comes news of the most significant blow yet to the UK's defences.
A secure government location in Cheltenham has also been hit
GCHQ destroyed, the building destroyed. That is a massive issue for us, strategic issue for us, but the evacuation was a success.
Two ballistic missiles have hit the vast circular GCHQ site.
It's one of the UK's main spy agencies and the key provider of signals and cyberintelligence.
no casualties at Fuzz Lane. So, so far casualties have been remarkably light... and we must expect that number to rise.
This is a deeply unsettling time... We're now broadcasting from a secure basement and we'll stay on air with continuous news programmes.
Can I suggest, PM, the crucial thing we need to determine in terms of our next move is what is the United States going to do?... But we do have to then have that conversation, I'm afraid.
It's the starkest observation any national security advisor could make... If not, London could be left with two choices – admit defeat or escalate to nuclear war.
I'd suggest we get the Secretary of State on line immediately.
We get the Secretary of State on, but at the same time, I think we have to pull out all the stops... and as much intelligence clearance as we can give to share with them.
The Chancellor, played by Jim Murphy, has a suggestion about how to win over Washington.

I wonder, in the privacy of these four walls, whether we ask the palace whether, of course, the king may speak to the president of the United States... And there may also come a time, of course, that we perhaps invite His Majesty to address the nation.
I think on the latter point that is important... I think you are potentially right, we should try every avenue, whichever works, I think is important.

Tensions then start to emerge between the Defence Chief and the Chancellor over why the UK has been left so badly defended... These warships are the only piece of British kit that can intercept ballistic missiles.
We have six Type 45s. We have one at sea... The others are in refit.
All six of them, but we usually try. So we own six... They are absolutely of no value in the circumstances we currently find ourselves right now.
Can they fire before they're destroyed?
So, the Type 45 that's at sea is well placed to defend itself... Its job is to protect the things it normally accompanies, like the carrier.
But if these other ones are in for refit, in dock, is there a capability to fire offensively at anything? Because they will be destroyed very soon.
So they're not at a state of readiness where their radars function or are any use... and they have no crews on board that could fight the vessel.
At no point do I ever remember the Treasury being told any of this.
From my position of CDS, I would have to say we've been reporting for more than two decades the state of UK defences... None of this should be a surprise to the government.
As we've learnt throughout this series, the UK only has very limited air defences... Given the scale of the strikes, it would have made little difference either way.
We'll all learn the lessons from this, of course, hopefully massively soon after the conflict, but one ship at sea?
Possibly two.
Okay. Peter, can I suggest... We're not going to solve that... We're not going to solve that, but exactly, exactly.
The National Security Advisor steers the discussion back to the immediate crisis because ministers must decide what to do.
We do need to be prepared for further waves... whether we're doing something about this on our own or with allies, I would suggest, critically first.
CDS may have some more. Two questions... One specific is, may I now sink that Akula II submarine I have under control?
The Defence Chief is talking about the Russian attack submarine that surfaced off the coast of Scotland the previous day. The Prime Minister gives the green light.
Yes, I think it is important that we message that for every action there will be a reaction.
And secondly, given we are where we are, do you believe we are effectively now in a state of general war with Russia... Are we at that point?
Not yet. We are at the point of let's find the target... And therefore it is proactively part of what it is trying to do.
The Prime Minister also asks again for what he calls strategic dilemmas to turn the pressure onto Russia from different, unexpected directions. And he has a suggestion.
Where is 16 Air Assault Brigade at this present moment of time? Where is Norway and Finland in support of us, given the changes on their border?
16 Air Assault Brigade is the Army's global response force... where the original attack on the Russian naval base in Murmansk occurred.
Murmansk, where many of those submarines are launched from near... Please do.
Across a corridor in his separate room, the CJO, or Chief of Joint Operations, is also tracking the Russian missile attack with his team of six expert advisors.
Tom Sharp, the former naval officer we met in the previous episode, and Professor Lucy Easthope, an expert on disaster relief, are the first to comment.
So London's on fire... No, but I do think there's a problem at this point in the conflict with the general public going, where's the military?
Lieutenant General Sir David Capewell as Chief of Joint Operations.
Much of the military activity that's going on is not seen and heard by the public... And I think the debate we would be operating inside is a massively volatile and toxic public debate.
Sir Bernard Gray, the defence procurement specialist, says the strikes, while shocking, are still limited.
It's still a calibrated attack, isn't it? It's not launch everything.
It's not hard and fast. It's not all out. That's what I mean by hard and fast.
A former senior civil servant, Matthew Saville, spells out the reality of the attack on the Ministry of Defence, where he used to work.
The seventh and eighth floors of the MoD going boom is like the glass is landing in Downing Street. That's what's happening.
When civilians are attacked on Oxford Street at Oxford Circus, that takes your emotional response into a new place.
Daniel Tarshish also used to work for the government and is an expert on national security.
He, along with Matthew, think the UK should use the strikes to sway their allies, especially the Americans, finally to join the fight.
The selection of a purely civilian target is all the other targets have had some kind of military association, even even he's broke if you've seen it.
The US ambassador should be being summoned into King Charles Street in number 10 walking by the MOD and the glass and the blood on the street.
Matthew is suggesting the US ambassador is invited to walk to the Foreign Office... and see first-hand the damage to the Ministry of Defence.
This is the moment when we can turn the tide within those critical on-the-fence groups out there... the message to the US and NATO after this should be, if not now, when?
I think the question of what we should do next is defined by the aggregate insult to the UK... The fait accompli point is made.
The war-fighting commander then issues a question to be sent back to the Cobra meeting.
When he mentions the NAC, he's referring to the North Atlantic Council, which is the main decision-making body at the NATO alliance.
So my question now is, to be transmitted very quickly, is that we are backed into a corner... Because unless a conventional solution is found, we have very few options left open to us.
It's thrilling... Buy early and save at newburyracecourse.co.uk.
I always feel like I'm rushing... To find out more, search Trinity Home Care.
Isolated and under fire, the UK does not have many options to fight back short of a nuclear strike... Tom Sharp, the former naval commander, helped me imagine how such an attack might unfold.

Deep beneath the North Atlantic, the Royal Navy has been using one of its attack submarines, HMS Astute, to track the boat... Finding a good position to strike, but also to evade any counter strikes, the captain runs through his final checks, then gives the order to fire.
The noise of a spearfish torpedo being launched is deafening... It last happened towards the end of the Second World War, when a British submarine destroyed a German U-boat in February 1945.
the Kremlin soon learns of its loss.
Mr. President, we have received some intel, which is grave indeed.
We have lost an Akula to submarine... we will ask him to explain how serious a setback this is
The Russian president contacts his commander, who's played by Robin Hagblom, a Finnish naval analyst.
Ah, Admiral, you have lost a submarine... Can you explain to us please what the implications of this are for the mission and how serious a setback it is?

This is indeed a more significant loss compared to the earlier destroyer which was sunk... The good news is that considering the small size of the British submarine force, they shouldn't be able to do much else.
The Russians have identified yet another British weak spot.

The Royal Navy only has five hunter-killer submarines in service... The other three have been out of action for more than two years, in large part because of a lack of capacity to carry out maintenance.
The fleet is also smaller than planned.
The original concept back in the 90s had been for the Navy to buy eight submarines... I've gone back and looked through a National Audit Office report on the programme.
It says the first order was placed in 1997, but a squeeze on the defence budget by the Treasury meant production was slowed down and costs increased.
Now only seven are being bought, with the final two not yet in service, almost 30 years after the initial order.
Back to the Russian naval commander.
Our nuclear submarine force is needed to protect our nuclear deterrent... we will have to defend the deterrent with all means possible, including unconventional ones.

So it is an operational setback which could have strategic consequences... We direct, therefore, that you move to a defensive position and concentrate primarily on preserving the rest of our flotilla.
In the Cobra Room, the Defence Chief is laying out his concerns to the Prime Minister

We need to recognise that every time we get in a missile attack, our stock of missiles is only getting smaller... that is the place that you will be left in because otherwise the country will be on its knees.
The Prime Minister, though, points out Russia's limitations too.
I also think we are in a dangerous position, though, about because we might run out, we shouldn't do something... how much more damage could we do to the task force, CDS, if that was our focus?
The Home Secretary draws on Britain's history of enduring Nazi bombing raids.
It might sound surprising, but experts in disaster relief say people don't tend to panic when under armed attack, instead they pull together.

I promise, if I may, from your position or your statement about the fact that we've had less actual casualties, the British public have responded with a certain blitz spirit... did a lot to calm the public down.
The defence chief is a lot less upbeat
Prime Minister, so a number of things... So we are still in the fight, but proportionately, our losses are significantly greater than the Russians have taken. Thank you.
Can I suggest, Peter, and we get the US Secretary of State back on the line?
The national security adviser also has a reality check for the room.
And you say to him that unless they get engaged and bring this to a halt... unless they stop it.
I also want to emphasize is that we go by the guardrails of the rule of law... and so we're not going to meet illegality with illegality.
Great. Let's speak to the U.S. Secretary of State, then we have a discussion briefly about further targets with CDS and the Secretary of State of Defense.
Our top American diplomat is played by Professor Phillips O'Brien.
He's helping us test a scenario in which Washington has relatively good relations with Moscow and isn't immediately mobilising to help London.
His face appears via video link on a big screen in the Cobra Room.
You'll hear the US President referred to as POTUS.
US Secretary of State, hello... now step in to support both NATO and an Article 5 and indeed us as allies with your assets that are currently in the North Atlantic?
Well, I think I have some good news that I've spoken with the Russians... And that is definitely the president's number one priority.
And do you believe the Russians when they give you that word?

We have always actually found the Russians to tell the president what the president believes to be true in these instances... So I do not believe that the Russians would be providing us automatically with deceptive information.
OK, I won't remind you of your own statements you made before POTUS was the president... which is a very important step of building that pressure on Russia, to stick to its word, please?
We would consider that if the Russians reject a ceasefire... We believe it's in your interest to have a ceasefire and in Russia's interest to have a ceasefire.
The Foreign Secretary.
Secretaries, we would have the cards if the US maintained its historic role as a key ally of the UK as we have yourselves from the Second World War and continuing.

Britain, as many European states decided to underinvest in defense over the past 30 years, you set up your own debt... And this is a situation into which you have put yourselves as much as anyone else.
Prime Minister, do we have to listen to any more of this?
Look, I think it's important that the US obviously sets out its case... If you force us in a corner, do not be surprised at what we have to do to guarantee our safety. Thank you.
As the call with the US Secretary of State ends, the head of NATO appears again on the line with some much needed good news.
The role is played by Elisabeth Brau.
Norway and the Netherlands have declared themselves willing to assist the UK... Let's see how this further evolves within the next few hours.
Thank you, Secretary General. It's nice to know we can rely on our friends at this moment.
While it won't shift the balance of power in the UK's favour, the decision by Norway and the Netherlands to join the fight is a big morale boost.
Denmark has also decided to be part of an emerging coalition of the willing.
All three nations operate the F-35 fast jet, significantly bolstering the UK's defences.
But the Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, along with Poland, all close allies of the UK, are preoccupied with their own security.
Russia has started moving troops to its border with NATO's eastern flank.
The National Security Advisor says the UK should seek to build as big a coalition as possible, even if it becomes a European NATO operation without the US.
PM, I think we have to proceed on the basis that we can't rely on the Americans, even in these circumstances... Or do you want to take the next move yourself?
I am hoping at this moment that the Russian second wave has completed and we have sunk the submarine.
He's told the submarine has been sunk.
Okay, so then not standing down, but having a watching brief... but at the same time developing to maturity the strategic dilemma elsewhere.
But the Prime Minister is not the only one giving orders.
In the Kremlin, the president has moved to his own small radio studio for a live broadcast.
The government of the Russian Federation now demands that Britain and its NATO allies desist from further armed attacks on the Russian Federation.
Simultaneously, the British side is alerted to a new message from Moscow.
Further armed attacks on the Russian Federation? Well, when I last looked, there's only been self-defence.
The Russian statement makes certain demands, as ever, as Putin does.
The president of Russia is willing to talk peace.
I am willing to talk peace.
However, we must make it very clear that we have specific and legitimate demands... and to avoid any thought of escalation.
Russia, we must remind you, is a nuclear-armed power
We must remind you as a nuclear arm power.
He reminds us that all the time and has done throughout the Ukraine conflict.
If we are forced to use this powerful arsenal, then the United Kingdom will simply cease to exist.
Basically evoking a nuclear threat that they would annihilate us.
We therefore demand that the chastised British government... and that its forces should all withdraw to its sovereign territory.
Somewhat ludicrous demands... I mean, we probably have one or two vessels that are in international waters.
These are non-negotiable.
These movements must be completed by midnight Moscow time today.
We need not remind anyone in this world of the consequences of a nuclear-armed attack.
If one missile or bomb falls on Russian sovereign territory, then the entire Russian Federation and all of its allies around the globe will combine to destroy Britain.
He then goes on to remind everyone that they're not bluffing.
We are not bluffing.
We are sincere as we have proven today.
We appeal to the reason of the British people.
Come to your senses British people.
Lay down your weapons.
Do not let your criminal and terrorist sponsoring government lead you into certain destruction.
That's all for the Saint Petersburg trolls, no doubt, to magnify.
They expect us to respond.
We expect the British government to respond appropriately to our reasonable demand by 12 midday London time.
It's 11 o'clock. Russia's president has raised the threat of a nuclear attack on the UK as he issues an ultimatum for a ceasefire.
Images posted on social media show empty shelves in supermarkets nationwide as people rush to buy bottled water, tinned food and other emergency supplies.
And there are growing traffic jams on the main roads out of London as residents in the capital ignore government advice to stay at home and instead try to flee
Downing Street says the Prime Minister's in an emergency meeting.
He has one hour to decide how to respond to Moscow's demands.
Coming up in episode five.
We have the nuclear deterrent.
What circumstances would we use it, Prime Minister?
The War Game was written and presented by me, Debra Haynes... For Sky News, the commissioning editor is Paul Stanworth and the executive producers are Sarah Whitehead and David Mapstone.
on a windswept walk in Carmarthen... Make money work for you.
